questions.question_text: While viewing packet capture data, you notice that one IP is sending and receiving traffic for multiple devices by modifying the IP header. Which option is making this behavior possible?

discussion.content: The answer is B. A typical N:1 NAT is just that: many IPs disguised in one single -most of the time- a public IP address. The way to differentiate what traffic belongs to what IP address is modifying the header: the source address is changed and also, the TCP port is changed as well (PAT).
Can we please explain why we say the answear is the option we choose, let's not just say it's c or b let us explain

comments.content:
No ... the answer is B.
I suppose that is what you wanted to say :-)

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Match the SMTP client reply codes with their function.
Select and Place:

discussion.content:
The SMTP reply codes seem similar to those for HTTP. The correct answer is:
2xx - Success
3xx - OK so far (Redirect)
4xx - Temporary failure (Client Error)
5xx - Permanent failure (Server Error)
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_SMTP_server_return_codes
The order is based in order of severity, i.e. 2xx would be ok so far, 3xx could be success, 4xx could be temporary failure, and 5xx is permanent failure

choices.A: Cookie information is sent in the URL.
choices.E: Cookie information is sent in the request body.
choices.F: Cookie information is sent in the response body.
choices.H: Cookie information is always private and encrypted.
choices.B: Cookie information is sent in the URI.
choices.C: Cookie information is sent in the response header.
choices.G: Cookie information is sent via the response codes.
choices.D: Cookie information is sent in the request header.
